column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	0	The Good Friday Agreement was overwhelmingly endorsed on this island in referendums
column2: North and South
column3: and through parliamentary ratification in Britain. It is an international treaty which has been lodged with the United Nations. The British Government
column4: in the Agreement
column5: committed to guaranteeing the rights of minorities
column6: and the Irish and British Governments are its co-guarantors. If the British Government presses ahead with its plan to abolish its Human Rights Act
column7: it will breach the terms of the Good Friday Agreement
column8: with highly negative consequences. The Government
column9: on behalf of Irish people
column10: must send a clear message that we will not tolerate any diminution in the provisions of the Good Friday Agreement. The full implementation of the Agreement and subsequent agreements is necessary.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	1	The commitment of Ireland to the promotion and protection of human rights is an underlying principle of Ireland's foreign policy and is a priority for the Government. Ireland is currently a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council and we pursue our human rights priorities in many international fora. Ireland is a firm supporter of the European Court of Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights system and will liaise regularly with the UK in relation to the Council of Europe Committee of Ministers' supervision of states' implementation of court judgments. Early in my Ministry
column2: I had the opportunity to meet the Council of Europe Secretary General
column3: Mr. Jagland
column4: and I reaffirmed Ireland's strong commitment in support of the European Convention on Human Rights. I should note clearly at the outset there is not at this time any legislation before the British Parliament at Westminster to repeal the 1998 UK Human Rights Act. Indeed
column5: the new British Government has not yet published its programme for government for this parliamentary term
column6: although it is expected to do so later this month. In the absence of any detailed proposal
column7: it is difficult to speculate on potential consequences. Obviously
column8: were any proposal to be made it would have to be carefully analysed. On the broad question of human rights and the Good Friday Agreement
column9: the views of the Government are clear and unchanged. The protection of human rights in Northern Irish law
column10: predicated on the European Convention on Human Rights
column11: is one of the key principles underpinning the Good Friday Agreement. As a guarantor of the Good Friday Agreement
column12: the Government takes very seriously its responsibility to safeguard the Agreement's principles and institutions. The fundamental role of human rights in guaranteeing peace and stability in Northern Ireland cannot be taken for granted and must at all times be fully respected. The Agreement is clear that there is an obligation to incorporate the European Convention on Human Rights into Northern Irish law and this is an ongoing obligation. We will follow developments closely. I plan to raise this matter this evening when I meet the Secretary of State
column13: Theresa Villiers.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	2	I thank the Minister for his reply. Even though the British programme for government has not yet been published
column2: in view of the commitment in the Conservative Party manifesto to scrap the Human Rights Act
column3: it is incumbent on the Minister and his colleagues in government to give a clear message to the Secretary of State that the British Government cannot renege on the provisions of an international treaty. As I stated earlier - the Minister referred to it as well - the Good Friday Agreement is an international treaty lodged by both Governments with the United Nations. Both Governments are co-guarantors of it. Can the Minister give us an assurance that he will make clear to the Secretary of State Villiers when he meets her today that under no circumstances can we tolerate any diminution in the terms of the Good Friday Agreement or in the provisions of an international treaty? What is the situation regarding the long-proposed bill of rights for Northern Ireland? Will the Minister outline to the British Government
column4: through the Secretary of State
column5: the value of the European Convention on Human Rights generally and that if the British were to depart from it
column6: the only states which would really welcome it are states with a less than positive attitude to human rights? Apart from the Northern Ireland issue
column7: which is of significant concern to us
column8: there is also the wider context of the safeguarding of human rights.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	3	I do not disagree with anything Deputy Brendan Smith has said. I assure him that placing human rights at the heart of the peace process in Northern Ireland is very much an ongoing obligation and an ongoing piece of work because that has helped to ensure the full participation
column2: trust and confidence of all communities. A shared emphasis on human rights and all that this implies is part of what makes the peace process both credible and effective. We will work continuously with the British Government and with the power-sharing Executive in Belfast to support the Good Friday Agreement and its institutions and the principles. We regard this as the foundational architecture underpinning the entire peace process and for this reason
column3: I was disappointed that a renewed commitment to a bill of rights for Northern Ireland
column4: based on the European Convention on Human Rights
column5: as provided for in the Agreement
column6: was not included in the recently completed Stormont House Agreement despite the best efforts and encouragement of this Government. However
column7: I assure Deputy Smith that I will avail of other opportunities to secure progress on this and other outstanding issues pertaining to the Good Friday Agreement and the St. Andrews Agreement.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	4	I thank the Minister for his comments. The Human Rights Act
column2: as the Minister implied
column3: is particularly important in regard to dealing with sensitive and contentious legacy issues.As we approach the marching season
column4: we should take note of the fact that all Parades Commission determinations are subject to the European Convention on Human Rights as interpreted in the Human Rights Act. A repeal of the Human Rights Act would have a devastating effect on the work of the commission and its determinations and guidelines. The European Court of Human Rights
column5: through the Human Rights Act
column6: has had a substantial impact on peace in Northern Ireland
column7: and it is that court which has held successive British Governments to account for countless human rights violations. Therefore
column8: it is a very important body
column9: and full participation in it by the British Government
column10: particularly from the point of view of Northern Ireland
column11: is absolutely essential.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	5	I wish to assure the House of my continued and intensive interest in the matter of any proposed or potential changes to the Human Rights Act. The Deputy mentioned the Conservative Party manifesto
column2: but beyond the manifesto pledge
column3: which promises to protect the basic rights such as the right to a fair trial and the right to life
column4: it is unclear at this stage what is envisaged by the Conservative Party or the British Government in respect of a bill of rights. I had the opportunity yesterday to have a brief meeting with my counterpart
column5: Philip Hammond
column6: the Foreign Secretary
column7: and I relayed to him our concern - a concern about which I had the opportunity of making a statement in the Seanad last week. It is my intention this evening to meet the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland
column8: Theresa Villiers
column9: and this issue will be very much on the agenda. However
column10: we await developments in terms of the publication of the legislative programme at Westminster and the subsequent draft Bill. I can assure Deputy Smith and the House that we will continue to make our position very clear on this important aspect of our relationship with the United Kingdom
column11: with particular reference to the Good Friday Agreement.

column1: #OliviaMitchell	unknown-#OliviaMitchell-party	unknown-#OliviaMitchell-dob	unknown-#OliviaMitchell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	6	Deputy Se√°n Crowe is not present
column2: so his question lapses.

column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	7	My question is to ask the Minister if he and the Irish Government will make clear the level of human rights due diligence they expect of Irish companies operating in Africa
column2: particularly in Irish Aid partner countries
column3: and if Ireland will take a leading role in ensuring that poverty reduction and a ##human rights-based approach to development are central to the work of multinational financial institutions.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	8	Our aid programme is focused on some of the poorest countries in sub-Saharan Africa. It is recognised internationally for its effectiveness and for its strong partnership with African governments and communities. Recent years have seen strong economic growth in many African countries
column2: which presents trade opportunities for Ireland and Irish companies. Many of our African partners are keen to foster opportunities for expanded trade and investment ties. As outlined in the Government‚Äôs policy for international development
column3: One World
column4: One Future
column5: we will strive to ensure that economic development is compatible with Ireland‚Äôs commitment to human rights. I expect Irish companies operating abroad to have full regard for human rights
column6: international law and the laws of the country in which they are operating. My Department‚Äôs work in this area is guided by the United Nations guiding principles on business and human rights
column7: which highlight the duty of states to protect against human rights abuses
column8: the corporate responsibility to respect human rights and the need for victims to have access to an appropriate remedy. A national plan on business and human rights
column9: which will assist companies in advancing the UN guiding principles
column10: is currently being drafted in consultation with civil society
column11: business and all interested parties.  Multilateral organisations play a vital role in building international agreement on development challenges. We believe that all development work
column12: including that of the multilateral organisations in which we actively participate
column13: should be framed explicitly in the context of sustainable development
column14: inclusive economic growth
column15: poverty reduction and the promotion and protection of human rights.

column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	9	I refer to a report commissioned by Tr√≥caire
column2: Where Aid Meets Trade
column3: which I helped to launch last week. The report is both informative and challenging. It is the first time private sector policy and development policies have been examined.As the Minister stated in his answer
column4: Irish Aid comes off remarkably well because the aid is 100% untied and 100% focused on poverty reduction. We know that African
column5: Latin American and Asian countries are keen to do business with Ireland and
column6: such is our reputation
column7: they expect an ethical engagement. In the One World
column8: One Future document there is a commitment to ensuring that economic development
column9: including engagement by Irish companies
column10: is compatible with our commitment to human rights. However
column11: there has been a rather poor track record to date. We know of companies that have been involved in land grabs and displacement. Certain employees of Irish companies are incentivised
column12: via the foreign earnings deduction
column13: to work in the Democratic Republic of the Congo
column14: yet there is no accompanying provision for human rights due diligence. What is happening in Qatar is frightening
column15: and Irish companies are working there. We do not see respect for human rights or the rights of workers there. I am asking that we ensure Irish companies operating in this countries engage with our embassies - they are now part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade - to ensure human rights due diligence from those companies.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	10	I am pleased that the Deputy acknowledges the statement in our One World
column2: One Future document. I agree with Deputy O'Sullivan that during the consultation period we should ensure we avail of the opportunity that will ultimately result in a robust regime. We are in the process of consulting with other Departments on the outline and content of our plan. An interdepartmental working group has been formed consisting of focal points from each Department. I take the point Deputy O'Sullivan has made about the trade mandate of my Department. It is important that we have the opportunity to consult widely and that this consultation be real and meaningful. I am unsure whether Deputy O'Sullivan was present at the open forum on 7 November in Dublin Castle. That provided an opportunity for non-governmental organisations
column3: academics
column4: businesses and public representatives to exchange views on the plan. It is important now
column5: in the context of the fact that we have received more than 30 submissions
column6: that we allow an opportunity for those submissions to be taken on board - certainly
column7: it is open to Deputy O'Sullivan to make a submission - to ensure that all possible elements are taken into consideration in the context of the relationship between Irish companies and Africa.

column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	11	There is a danger that economic growth is being seen to equate with poverty reduction and a reduction in inequality. There are some interesting statistics from Africa. For example
column2: in Nigeria
column3: economic growth in the past ten years has increased by 6% per year
column4: yet on the human development index the country is placed 152nd out of 176. Equally
column5: Botswana has considerable economic growth but minimal poverty reduction
column6: whereas Ghana has modest growth but significant poverty reduction levels. We cannot simply speak of economic growth without looking at how exactly it impacts on poverty reduction and inequality. I wish to draw the Minister's attention to the G8 New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition. This is a rather concerning development
column7: because there is the potential to do the opposite to what is intended in terms of food exports
column8: biofuels and land grabs on a vast corporate scale. Given Ireland's reputation
column9: we need to stand up
column10: and the Minister and the Government must be a strong voice in this regard. I hope that in the context of the three conferences coming up
column11: Ireland and the Minister take the opportunity to be heard.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	12	As I mentioned
column2: our document commits to the implementation by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Africa Strategy
column3: which underlines the need to respond to requests from our African partners from time to time to develop a more rounded relationship. This includes economic ties as well as a more intensified political relationship with our bilateral partners. As Deputy O'Sullivan may be aware
column4: we have a total of 11 embassies in Africa
column5: including in Nairobi
column6: Kenya and Freetown
column7: Sierra Leone
column8: both of which opened only last year. We now have embassies in the strongest economies of western
column9: eastern and southern Africa
column10: particularly Nigeria
column11: Kenya and South Africa. What we need to do now is to ensure that we can move towards the achievement of a sustainable solution to poverty.In this regard
column12: countries need to generate their own revenues through sustained and equitable economic policies and we will be looking towards a greater level of employment
column13: revenue
column14: growth
column15: trade and investment. I am very conscious of the points Deputy O'Sullivan makes. I would hope that
column16: at the earliest opportunity
column17: we will be in a position to have an acceptable plan and a form of due diligence that will ensure that best practice from a human rights point of view exists in the relationship between all Irish companies and the African nations.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	13	It is just over two weeks since the British general election. It appears the referendum in regard to the continued British membership of the European Union could be held in 2016 and the latest reports from Westminster suggest the parliamentary Bill which will pave the way for the vote will be published next week. We are all conscious that each sovereign country makes its own decisions. At the same time
column2: however
column3: we have a major selfish and strategic interest in Britain continuing its membership of the EU. There is over ‚Ç¨1 billion of bilateral trade per week between the two countries and our two economies are very strongly linked. Therefore
column4: there is an onus on us to get a clear message to the British Government about the value and strength of its continued membership of the EU
column5: which will also be beneficial to our country.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	14	The debate in the United Kingdom regarding its relationship with the European Union

is followed extremely closely by the Government. That focus will now only intensify following the recent general election in Britain and Prime Minister Cameron‚Äôs commitment to holding a referendum on the country‚Äôs EU membership by 2017. My Government colleagues and I have been clear in voicing our view that joint British-Irish membership has been very beneficial to our country and our relationship with the UK. The important role the EU has played in the context of Northern Ireland should also not be forgotten
column2: as the Taoiseach emphasised recently in a speech in Belfast. The Taoiseach also restated our view when he spoke to Prime Minister Cameron by phone following the re-election of the Conservative Government in recent weeks. Our unique relationship with the UK
column3: in economic
column4: social
column5: cultural and historical terms
column6: means we have a deep interest in the outcome of this debate about that country‚Äôs future in Europe. We also value the contribution the UK has made to the EU during the four decades we have been members together. We share a similar approach in many key policy areas. Given the importance we attach to their ongoing membership
column7: a key priority will be ensuring that our UK partners remain fully aware of the potential consequences for Ireland of any fundamental change in the nature of their membership of the EU. I have addressed many of these points directly with the Foreign Secretary
column8: Mr. Philip Hammond
column9: including yesterday
column10: Monday
column11: when we spoke at the Foreign Affairs Council meeting in Brussels. I also wrote to him following his recent re-appointment and will remain in close contact with him in the time ahead. I will also maintain close contact with the Secretary of State
column12: Ms Theresa Villiers
column13: with whom I will be meeting this evening in Dublin
column14: on a range of issues pertaining to Northern Ireland and our shared interests. A debate in the UK on this important issue may be seen as an opportunity to highlight the many benefits of EU membership. We will work closely in the coming period with both our British and EU partners with the objective of ensuring continued UK membership of the EU.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	15	I thank the Minister for his reply. Will he take the opportunity this evening
column2: in his meeting with the Secretary of State
column3: to outline very clearly to her that a very strong pro-European Union view is held throughout Northern Ireland? In fact
column4: as the Minister mentioned in his reply
column5: all of us recognise the very valuable contribution the EU has made to the political advances and the major progress in Northern Ireland over the past 17 or 18 years. If Britain were to leave the Single Market
column6: it would be catastrophic from our point of view. I represent the constituency of Cavan-Monaghan which has a very long land border with Northern Ireland. I grew up along the Border
column7: with its customs posts and permanent vehicle checkpoints.I do not want to see either in situ along the Border ever again. I sincerely hope the Minister will continue to send a strong message to the British Government that membership of the EU
column8: with access to 500 million people in a Single Market and the very valuable trade on a bilateral basis throughout the EU
column9: is of critical importance to all the people on this island. It is important to reflect there is a far stronger pro-EU sentiment in areas outside of England.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	16	The matter of the EU-UK relationship is a strategic priority for the Government because we believe British membership of the EU is fundamental to Ireland's interests on a variety of levels
column2: not least those evidenced by Deputy Smith. It now seems clear there will be a referendum
column3: most likely in 2017
column4: and that means our focus must intensify. The UK knows how much we value its presence in the EU and I and my Government colleagues have made that clear on a number of occasions
column5: as did the Taoiseach
column6: most recently in his conversation with Prime Minister Cameron. Extensive work has been under way across a range of Departments for some time to ensure a full understanding of the various issues at stake. My Department has been working alongside other Departments to identify issues and areas of foreign policy that could be affected by the potential withdrawal of the UK from the EU. Our main objective remains helping to keep the UK in the EU
column7: rather than mitigating the effects of a potential withdrawal.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	17	Would the Minister agree the lacuna or lack of clarity that will exist for some time will probably be detrimental to attracting inward investment to Northern Ireland? Such investment benefits the entire island. I hope a clear message can be sent
column2: namely
column3: that trade and investment are very important from the point of view of Britain's continued membership of the EU
column4: from which we also benefit. Does the Minister have any inkling of what the British want to renegotiate regarding its terms of membership of the EU?

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	18	It seems that there are three issues upon which this debate will pivot. The first is the area the British Government describes as over-regulation. The second is the matter of immigration
column2: workers' rights and labour law. The third is the role of national parliaments. No formal plans have been presented and
column3: therefore
column4: we are not yet in a position to outline the precise approach we will take. The UK
column5: as a key member of the EU over the past 40 years
column6: continues to make an important contribution to the ongoing development of the Union. As our closest neighbour and as a partner
column7: we share many similarities with it in terms of our economic model and legal system. We value its perspective on how we can continue to improve the effectiveness of the Union.  I wish to assure the House that over the next few months and as the debate intensifies
column8: one will see a very strong and close relationship across a range of Government Departments
column9: led by the Taoiseach in his relationship with Prime Minister Cameron. I understand they are arranging to meet very shortly
column10: perhaps over the coming weeks. I have already met Foreign Secretary Hammond and we also agreed to meet in London in June. I wish to assure the House that when this debate intensifies
column11: the Government will be most vociferous in ensuring that the British Government is clear on our position. There may be areas in which we will be in a position to assist it.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	19	This year
column2: we are working for global agreement in three major international conferences on sustainable development. The conferences are interlinked. They are on financing for development in Addis Ababa in July
column3: on a new framework for global development at the United Nations in New York in September and on a new climate change agreement in Paris in December. The aim is to deliver a new and transformative sustainable development agenda
column4: with sustainable development goals up to 2030. The Addis Ababa conference
column5: which will be attended by the Minister of State
column6: Deputy Sherlock
column7: will seek to unlock the range of financing sources required to implement the new universal goals. These include domestic resource mobilisation
column8: private sector contributions and official development assistance
column9: ODA
column10: which remains critical for the poorest countries. The Government remains fully committed to reaching the 0.7% target and to making further progress towards it as our economy continues to recover. Ireland is a world leader in the proportion of our aid which goes to least developed countries and we strongly support the UN target of providing between 0.15% and 0.2% of GNI for the least developed countries. Currently
column11: we exceed that target. Issues of taxation will be central to the financing of sustainable development. We believe the most effective way to deal with global tax issues is through the OECD. In an effort to ensure the involvement of the developing world in these processes
column12: the Minister for Finance
column13: at the OECD
column14: has previously called for all countries to undertake spill-over analyses of the impact of their taxation regimes on the developing world
column15: similar to the analysis already commissioned by the Department of Finance in respect of Ireland.

column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	20	The tax issue is vital to economic justice. We have seen already the harm that has been done by tax and financial systems which facilitated tax dodging
column2: illicit financial flows and the illegal movement of money or capital from one country to another. There is a frightening statistic that in one year there was an estimated loss of $634 billion for developing countries
column3: and another that $5.3 trillion of effective subsidies went to fossil fuel industries. Ireland sits on quite a number of multinational and international fora and
column4: as we have such a good reputation and as our aid is second to none
column5: we can also be a voice when it comes to economic justice. There is a need for us to be strong on the five main areas of trade
column6: debt
column7: tax
column8: gender and climate. While I mean no disrespect to the Minister of State
column9: Deputy Sherlock
column10: it is disappointing that the Minister
column11: Deputy Flanagan
column12: is not going to Addis Ababa. My understanding is that very high level delegations are coming from many of the African countries. There is a need for Ireland to be much stronger on these issues. Is Ireland committed to the ODA target by 2020?

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	21	I wish to assure the Deputy and the House that the Government will be represented by a Minister at the conference in Addis Ababa. Ireland has a proud record of attendance at these conferences and of influencing the outcomes of many international fora. The Deputy will be aware that the Minister for Finance
column2: Deputy Noonan
column3: has the lead on tax issues. My Department works closely with the Department of Finance on the role of taxation in development. Ireland takes the position that the most effective way to deal with global tax issues is through the OECD. It is
column4: therefore
column5: important that the United Nations works on taxation and that it takes into account the ongoing work at the OECD. It is necessary for us to adopt an approach that avoids conflict between the various organisations' activities. I would be concerned about having a number of approaches rather than one approach. It is in the best interests of our endeavours to ensure that we work and deal with global tax issues through the OECD.

column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	22	Lack of action and lack of courage on issues of economic justice are very strong contributing factors for the people who are migrating in vast numbers and at great risk from various African countries.I wonder about the role of officialdom versus the role of Government intentions. When our Ministers return from these three conferences
column2: my wish is that they will tell us they had the courage
column3: passion and commitment to speak out in a strong way on issues of tax justice and they did not take a cautious or conservative approach. The Minister spoke about civil society in his previous reply to me. There has been a joint civil society statement on the second draft of the Addis Ababa outcome document. Has the Minister taken this and the various issues on board
column4: because civil society has concerns? In many cases they are the people working on the ground with immediate experience of the effect of some of these policies which are made far away from these countries.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	23	The parameters of a useful agreement at Addis Ababa would need to be broad if they are to support the new sustainable development goals
column2: which we hope will be adopted in New York in September. These goals are universal in nature and will be implemented by all countries. It is essential
column3: therefore
column4: that all contribute to a successful outcome to the finance and development conference in Addis Ababa. I will make a brief reference to the Government's commitment to Ireland's overseas aid programme
column5: which is at the heart of our foreign policy. It is articulated in the recently published document
column6: The Global Island: Ireland's Foreign Policy for a Changing World. Our policy on international development restates the programme for Government commitment to achieving the United Nations' target of providing 0.7% of GNP for overseas development aid once our economic circumstances permit. Since 2011
column7: the Government has allocated more than ‚Ç¨3 billion to overseas development aid. In 2011
column8: some ‚Ç¨657 million was allocated
column9: and between 2012 and 2013 the level of contribution increased from ‚Ç¨629 million to ‚Ç¨637 million. The final outturn for 2014 shows Ireland contributed slightly in excess of ‚Ç¨610 million to overseas aid. For 2015
column10: we have again allocated a sum in excess of ‚Ç¨600 million to overseas development aid. We will continue to endeavour to increase this sum until we reach the committed target.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	24	The Minister had a very successful visit by the Chinese Prime Minister

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	25	The Government follows events in Tibet and the Xinjiang Uighur region on a very close basis. Ireland
column2: together with EU partners
column3: believes that constructive dialogue between the Chinese Government and representatives of the Dalai Lama is the best way to address differences and tensions in Tibet and to reach a solution that respects Tibetan culture
column4: language
column5: religion and identity. It is important for the long-term peace and stability of the region that the two sides come to an agreement on the future of Tibet. To this end
column6: we continue to encourage a resumption of meaningful dialogue. Ireland respects the territorial integrity of China and recognises the necessity of preventing acts of terrorism
column7: as well as the adoption of counter-terrorism strategies that seek to prevent acts of terrorism. We condemn all acts of violence. However
column8: we also take the view that security forces should practice restraint in exercising their competences to avoid providing fuel for further radicalisation and support the EU‚Äôs call on the Chinese authorities to address some of the deep-rooted causes of the frustration of the Uighurs

column10: language and religion is respected. Through the formal framework of the EU-China human rights dialogue

column15: including the rights of persons belonging to religious minorities. The dialogue allowed the two sides to have a detailed exchange of views on a wide range of human rights issues. There was a specific focus on recent developments in China
column16: including the rights of persons belonging to minorities

column18: Mr. Wang Yi.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	26	I welcome the Minister's comments. I recall that as a backbencher
column2: he expressed concerns regarding the repression of religious minorities

column5: their Buddhist religion and their profound and ancient traditions. There has been a great deal of outrage recently about what is happening in Crimea. The reality is that in 1958 and 1959 the People's Republic of China essentially absorbed a millennia-old nation. The World Uyghur Congress has provided a long list of instances of oppression of the Uyghur people. column6: including in the construction of a pipeline to export local petroleum resources to other parts of China. The Uyghurs are the only population in China consistently subjected to executions for political crimes
column7: and these executions are both summary and public. A UN training seminar for Uyghur youth took place in Geneva in November

column10: which used to be known as East Turkestan. The Uyghur Government

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	27	We will continue to raise our concerns on these issues with our European partners. Last weekend
column3: the Taoiseach
column4: the Chinese Premier
column5: Mr. Li Keqiang
column6: the Chinese Foreign Minister
column7: Mr. Wang Yi
column8: and I had a good discussion in a spirit of friendship in which we emphasised Ireland's deep commitment to human rights
column9: the public concern in Ireland regarding human rights in China and the issues upon which we respectfully disagreed

column11: open and informal discussion with my Chinese counterpart on these issues. We discussed the situation in Tibet
column12: with particular reference to the humanitarian situation in the aftermath of recent earthquakes in Nepal.I assure the Deputy that we will avail of every opportunity to raise the concern contained in his question.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	28	We have been reflecting recently

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	30	Before Christmas the Stormont House Agreement averted the collapse of the Northern Ireland Executive and legislative assembly
column2: and impending financial suspension. At that time
column3: Sinn F√©in agreed to Tory welfare cuts

column5: is the Minister satisfied with the implementation of the agreement alongside the established timescale for progress on different issues?

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	31	We are now entering an important point in the implementation process of the Stormont House Agreement. A number of target dates over a range of the areas included in the agreement will arise in the weeks ahead. To achieve these will require a concerted effort and an intensive political investment from the Northern Ireland Executive
column2: from the UK Government and from the Irish Government. It is important to recall how far we have come already in terms of the collective achievement of getting the Stormont House Agreement over the line in December and the progress made since then in implementing it. Since the start of the year
column3: the two Governments and the Northern Ireland Executive parties have held two comprehensive formal review meetings. In February
column4: a report on new priorities for North-South co-operation was agreed at a North-South Ministerial Council meeting in Belfast. Officials from Dublin
column5: London and Belfast are preparing the groundwork for legislation to establish the new institutions for dealing with the past and the Northern Ireland party leaders continue to meet on a weekly basis to take forward work across the broad areas of responsibility they undertook in Stormont House. It is disappointing that difficulties have recently arisen around the welfare element of the Stormont House Agreement. The Government is committed to the implementation of the totality of the provisions of the agreement and it is important to ensure that the developments around the welfare issue do not have a corrosive impact on the wider implementation of the agreement. Now that the Westminster elections are over and a new UK Government is in place
column6: there is an opportunity and obligation to refocus our efforts to implement the next phases of the agreement. I spoke with each of the Northern Ireland Executive party leaders in recent days and set out the Irish Government‚Äôs views in this regard. This is an opportunity to demonstrate that politics delivers and to create a way forward on issues that have been a source of difficulty for far too long. I will also discuss these issues with the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland
column7: Theresa Villiers
column8: when I meet her later today
column9: following on from our constructive telephone conversation last week. There are challenges ahead
column10: not least on the issue of welfare
column11: but I am confident that
column12: working together in good faith
column13: the parties in the Executive can deliver the solutions the people of Northern Ireland expect and deserve. The next implementation and review meeting will take place in late June
column14: when a six-month progress report will also be published by the two Governments. I will continue to keep this House informed of progress in that regard.

column1: #BrendanSmith	unknown-#BrendanSmith-party	unknown-#BrendanSmith-dob	unknown-#BrendanSmith-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	32	I thank the Minister for his detailed response and welcome the ongoing work on the matter. column2: with a view towards the introduction of legislation in Westminster. My officials continue to follow this process closely. As I mentioned previously to the Deputy
column3: in most legacy cases
column4: An Garda S√≠och√°na will continue to be responsible for investigations into deaths related to the Troubles in this jurisdiction where successful prosecutions have not resulted. column2: it is very important that the appropriate mechanisms be put in place to deal with the legacy of the past and that we try in some way to ease the suffering and burden that has been placed on so many families through the needless loss of life and the murder of so many innocent people over the period known as the Troubles. column4: including the determination of applications for permission to parade in various areas?

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	35	I and my officials continue to monitor the situation with regard to parades very closely

#MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	37	In view of the improving relations between America and Cuba and Ireland's signing a memorandum of understanding with Cuba

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	38	The Secretary General of my Department
column2: Mr. Burgess

column4: as noted
column5: signed a memorandum on the establishment of a mechanism for political consultations. This will provide a useful structure for official level dialogue on international issues in the future. column1: #MaureenOSullivan	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-party	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-dob	unknown-#MaureenOSullivan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	39	The memorandum of understanding has been long awaited and is very welcome. column7: for example

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	40	Officials in my Department have consulted widely with other Departments on this issue and also with the Central Bank. column2: we raised the matter in political consultations with the United States and we restated our position. I recognise the limitations on what the US Federal Government can do in this matter
column3: given the strict separation of powers between the executive and legislature in its system. However

column5: and the steps he has taken so far must be acknowledged fully.The extraterritorial legislation in question is congressional legislation
column6: in particular the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Helms-Burton Act of 1996. I welcome President Obama's willingness to engage with the US Congress in this matter and to the lifting of the legislation in question. The information provided by the US has been forwarded to the Minister
column7: Deputy Noonan
column8: in the Department of Finance and to the Central Bank for further consideration of how we might proceed further.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	45	The achievement of relief for undocumented Irish migrants in the United States is a priority for the Government in our contacts with that country. column4: with the US Congress and at state level

column6: the Taoiseach commended him on the executive action he announced last year. This action is currently the subject of legal proceedings in the US federal courts. column1: visas
column2: but who would be required to return to Ireland for their issuance and hence would require waivers for their prior periods of undocumented residence. He expressed the hope that a political way forward on this issue could be found to encourage progress on a comprehensive package of legislation by the US Congress. column3: have been adequate.

column1: #CharlesFlanagan	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-party	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-dob	unknown-#CharlesFlanagan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	51	The earthquakes in Nepal on 25 April and 12 May had horrific humanitarian consequences for the region. Irish Aid
column2: working with Irish non-governmental organisations
column3: NGOs
column4: is fully committed to making a contribution to the response and we are working closely with the European Union and United Nations. The European Commission allocated ‚Ç¨22.6 million in assistance to the Government of Nepal to help address urgent needs and the United Nations has appealed for $423 million to address critical needs in the coming three months. As of 13 May
column5: $58 million has been contributed by the international community. Thus far
column6: the Government has announced the provision of ‚Ç¨1.5 million in Irish Aid support for the humanitarian response in the immediate aftermath of the earthquake. In responding
column7: Irish Aid has focused on the provision of life-saving assistance
column8: including shelter
column9: water and hygiene supplies for displaced persons. Our funding has been channelled through our NGO partners. We are also providing more than 100 tonnes of emergency supplies through the rapid response initiative. They include tents
column10: blankets
column11: tarpaulins
column12: water and sanitation equipment
column13: all of which are most urgently needed at this stage in the crisis. To date
column14: more than 63 tonnes of supplies have arrived and are being distributed across the region. Based on lessons learned from previous crises
column15: the United Nations has put in place clear systems to ensure the most effective
column16: efficient and rapid delivery of aid possible. The difficult terrain
column17: a second major earthquake last week and the capacity of local infrastructure present significant challenges for the relief effort. My officials will continue to liaise with partners on this tragic humanitarian issue and review what further assistance Ireland can provide.  In terms of our consular response
column18: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade opened its emergency response centre on Saturday
column19: 25 April. An experienced consular team maintained contact with families and provided practical assistance and support to citizens in the affected areas of Nepal. The Department quickly accounted for the safety of all Irish citizens known to be living or working in the affected areas. Co-operation with the European Union and international partners formed a key part of our crisis response. The Department is continuing to provide assistance to Irish citizens in Nepal and is keeping its travel advice under review.

column2: I understand the position has improved significantly in recent days. Deputy Durkan will be interested to learn that Ireland is increasing its funding for humanitarian assistance to families who were displaced by the recent earthquakes. The Government announced additional funding of ‚Ç¨500
column3: 000 today
column4: bringing Ireland's total contribution to ‚Ç¨1.5 million. This increase in funding has been provided in response to the mounting humanitarian need that has become apparent as a result of ongoing assessments by Irish Aid partners on the ground.  I assure the Deputy that the Department
column5: in conjunction with Irish non-governmental organisations
column6: will continue to closely monitor the position and I will be pleased to keep the House informed of developments in the region.

column1: #PaulKehoeFG	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-party	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-dob	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	149	The publication of recorded crime statistics has been temporarily suspended by the Central Statistics Office
column2: CSO. This decision was made on foot of the Garda Inspectorate report on crime investigation published on 11 November 2014. That report raised a number of issues regarding the accuracy of recorded crime administrative data in Ireland. The CSO understands that while these issues relate to the work of the Garda S√≠och√°na
column3: they may have an impact on the level and classification of CSO recorded crime statistics. As such
column4: the office could not continue to publish official statistics without a detailed examination of the issues raised by the inspectorate. column1: #AengusOSnodaighSF	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-party	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-dob	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	151	It has been a cause of major concern for several years that crimes were recorded in different ways in different parts of the country and even within the city of Dublin itself. As a member of Dublin City Council's joint policing committee
column2: I recall being presented with reports in which there was clearly a difference in how crime statistics were compiled for different districts
column3: even where districts were only two or three miles apart. It was only when one amalgamated the figures for two or three subcategories of crime that one would arrive at the true figure for a particular crime. It is vital
column4: at the very least
column5: that everybody involved in gathering statistics in regard to crime use the same terminology. In particular
column6: there should be a clearly understood rationale for referring to a crime under a different title and an explanation as to why some crimes are recorded under a different category. In the case of theft
column7: for instance
column8: a number of categories might be used
column9: including theft from a vehicle
column10: theft from a house
column11: larceny
column12: theft from a shop
column13: and so on. During my time on the joint policing committee
column14: we sometimes had to ask the superintendent presenting the report to give an explanation of the differences between crimes and the reason for their categorisation in the statistics. In addition
column15: we often queried instances in which crimes were recorded as supposedly being solved. The problem was that "solved" did not necessarily mean there was a conviction at the end of it. It might mean
column16: for example
column17: that the garda√≠ involved in the investigation had managed to identify a suspect. There was not necessarily a delivery for the victim of the crime. There probably is a need to have different subcategories for particular crimes
column18: but the overall theft figure
column19: for example
column20: should also be provided. This is not just important for those of us who look at these statistics and ask about them in this Chamber. It is important because it influences how the Garda authorities allocate scarce resources. They must be able to respond quickly where they see a crime surge happening in a three-month or six-month period
column21: for instance
column22: by ensuring that adequate manpower and resources
column23: including vehicles
column24: investment in buildings and so on
column25: are directed towards areas of highest crime. That can only be done effectively if the statistics stand up
column26: and
column27: as I understand it
column28: it was because there were doubts in this regard that the CSO suspended the provision of the information. It is to be hoped that when the data are finally released
column29: we can be confident that they stand up. They should
column30: in addition
column31: be presented under the same categories as those used for the Garda national crime figures.

column1: #PaulKehoeFG	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-party	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-dob	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-19 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	152	I join the Deputies in welcoming the resumed publication of the CSO quarterly recorded crime statistics in late June. I accept that the suspension of the provision of this information has been a concern for Members
column2: including Deputies opposite
column3: several of whom have raised it on more than one occasion in the House in recent months. At the beginning of 2012
column4: the Garda Inspectorate conducted a major review of how crime is investigated in Ireland. This led to the publication of a report in November 2014 which examined issues such as training resource management
column5: treatment of persons in custody and many other areas which are not of relevance to crime statistics. The main focus of the report was on cases of assault
column6: burglary
column7: domestic violence
column8: fatal crime and robbery reported between 2011 and 2012. As part of its analysis
column9: the inspectorate examined 1
column10: 500 crime records on the PULSE system
column11: spoke to 1
column12: 000 garda√≠
column13: examined 158 calls for service received in the 12 months up to mid-2012
column14: visited external stakeholders and other police services
column15: sampled computer-aided dispatch and paper records
column16: collected data on staffing and employment levels
column17: and visited stations and control rooms in various Garda divisions to observe operations. Of particular interest in respect of the CSO was the inspectorate review of how crime is reported and recorded by An Garda S√≠och√°na. Specifically
column18: the report raised several concerns in regard to the accuracy of recorded crime and other administrative data
column19: including the non-recording of crimes on PULSE. In fact
column20: the inspectorate estimated that more than 30% of offences reported were not being recorded on PULSE. It identified evidence of a lack of timely recording of incidents
column21: lack of sufficient detail on PULSE narratives
column22: misclassification of incidents
column23: including to non-crime categories
column24: incorrect reclassification of incidents - again
column25: including to and from non-crime categories - incorrect application of detention status to some incidents
column26: and shortening and alteration of narrative fields to justify subsequent decisions on detention status. While the issues raised in the report relate primarily to the work of An Garda S√≠och√°na
column27: they also have implications for the crime statistics produced by the CSO. In its response to the findings of the Garda Inspectorate
column28: the CSO said it viewed with concern any issues which could have an impact on its official quarterly statistics. The crime data published by the CSO
column29: the office noted
column30: depend entirely on the Garda S√≠och√°na's systems and procedures in respect of recorded crime. In November 2014
column31: the director general of the CSO contacted the Garda Commissioner with a view to examining the statistical implications of the inspectorate report. The CSO then commenced work assessing the statistical issues arising. This involved a detailed analysis of both the PULSE system and other Garda administrative data sets by CSO crime section personnel.This work
column32: which is an important step in ensuring the quality and coverage of crime statistics
column33: delayed the current schedule of publication of the crime statistics by the CSO. The CSO will publish a more detailed response by the end of June 2015
column34: identifying the extent of the impact on statistics in respect of coverage and classification from the issues highlighted in the Garda Inspectorate report. As a precaution
column35: until the conclusion of the CSO review process
column36: the CSO suspended the release of any new statistical information and publications that incorporate PULSE-administered data. The publication of the quarterly record of crime reports of quarter three and quarter four of 2014 and the Garda crime statistics 2009-2013 have been delayed as a direct result of this review process. The CSO will resume publication of quarterly reports in late 2015. The Garda Inspectorate report on crime investigation forms an important component of the overall justice reform programme
column37: which is currently under way and in respect of which significant progress has already been made. An Garda S√≠och√°na has established an implementation steering group to focus on the implementation of short
column38: medium and long-term recommendations in the report and to assist in the overall reform process a strategic transformation office has been established at Garda headquarters to co-ordinate the implementation of reforms arising from the report. As part of this process
column39: An Garda S√≠och√°na is reviewing all aspects of how crime is being recorded and classified as a result of the recommendations made in the inspectorate's report. A new instant recording process
column40: which addresses the challenges identified in the report
column41: has been developed and is currently being piloted in three Garda divisions. The pilot is focused on achieving data integrity for both crime and non-crime incidents reported to the Garda information services. That is a comprehensive reply for the Deputies opposite.
